Pandemic.X86 package¶

Subpackages¶

Submodules¶

Pandemic.X86.X86MetaData module¶

This file contains enumerations (in the style of Enumerate) for common objects in X86:

  • Prefixes: PF1Elt
  • Mnemonics: MnemElt
  • Register types:
    • 8-bit registers: R8Elt
    • 16-bit registers: R16Elt
    • 32-bit registers: R32Elt
    • Segment registers: SegElt
    • Control registers: CntElt
    • Debug registers: DbgElt
    • FPU registers: FPUElt
    • MMX registers: MMXElt
    • XMM registers: XMMElt
  • Memory sizes: FlagElt
  • Flags: FlagElt

Pandemic.X86.X86Internal module¶

class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.FarTarget[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Operand

Base class for memory operands specified as segment:offset pairs.

Off¶

Integer value for the offset. 16-bits in AP16, 32-bits in AP32.

Seg¶

16-bit integer value for the segment.

init(hashcode, seg, off, mask)[source]¶
class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.GeneralReg[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Register

GeneralReg gets its own class in the hierarchy, so we can distinguish them from other types of registers.

class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Immediate[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Operand

Immediates are held in guarded integers, so that they never exceed their bounds (i.e., 8-bit values are always 0 <= value <= 0xFF).

init(hashcode, value, mask)[source]¶
value¶

The integer value of an immediate constant.

class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.MemExpr(seg, size)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Operand

Base class for memory operands.

Variables:Seg (SegElt) – the segment in which the access takes place
Disp¶

Integer displacement; may be None. 16-bit for Mem16, 32-bit for Mem32.

HashIndex()[source]¶

Used internally for hashing the index component. Differs in Mem16 and Mem32 objects.

Returns a string based on those in parts, with + between the non-empty strings contained therein.

Parameters:parts (string list) – string parts (some may be "")
Return type:string

class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Operand[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for X86 operands, containing some of the Python glue.

class Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Register[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Operand

The base class for all registers in X86 assembly language. The constructor takes two parameters: value and adjust_value. If adjust_value is False, value is interpreted as an enumeration element, i.e. some object that is a derivative of EnumElt, which must have the same type as the regtype member. If adjust_value is True, then value is interpreted as an integer, and it is used to construct an EnumElt of type regtype.

Variables:
  • value (EnumElt) – an enumeration element corresponding to the particular register being represented
  • regtype (EnumElt) – a derivative of EnumElt corresponding to the type of register a derived class represents
IntValue()[source]¶

Retrieve the integer value 0-7 from the held value.

Return type:integer
init(value, hashcode, regtype, adjust_value=False)[source]¶
Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.X86Hexify(value)[source]¶

Function to make an X86-style hexadecimal string. I.e., it should end in h, should not begin with 0x, and should begin with a 0 if the first nibble is A-F.

Parameters:value (integer) –
Return type:string

Pandemic.X86.X86 module¶

The main module for representing X86 instructions and operands. Generally, clients will need to import both this module and X86MetaData.

NumOps()[source]¶

Return the number of operands (0-3) possessed by this instruction.

Return type:integer
exception Pandemic.X86.X86.InvalidInstruction[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

This exception may be thrown during decoding, if an attempt to decode an undefined instruction is made, or if an encoded instruction specifies an illegal operand. For example, some operands are encoded in such a way that they might specify a register or memory location, but one of those possibilities could be illegal.

class Pandemic.X86.X86.Mem16(seg, size, basereg=None, indexreg=None, disp=None, adjust_values=False)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.MemExpr

DefaultSeg()[source]¶

16-bit memory expressions use SS by default if the base register is Bp, and DS otherwise.

Return type:SegElt
String()[source]¶
class Pandemic.X86.X86.Mem32(seg, size, basereg=None, indexreg=None, scalefac=0, disp=None, adjust_values=False)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.MemExpr

Class representing 32-bit memory expressions.

Variables:
  • BaseReg (R32Elt) – The base register, or None.
  • IndexReg (R32Elt) – The index register, or None.
DefaultSeg()[source]¶

32-bit memory expressions use SS by default if the base register is Ebp or Esp, and DS otherwise.

Return type:SegElt
HashIndex()[source]¶

Used internally for hashing the index component. Differs in Mem16 and Mem32 objects.

ScaleFac¶

32-bit memory expressions may scale the index register by this value, which is in the range of 0-3. It should be set to 0 if there is no scale factor. Otherwise, it corresponds to multiplying by 1 << ScaleFac. That is, a value of 1 corresponds to multiplying by 2; 2 corresponds to multiplication by 4; and 3 denotes multiplication by 8.

String()[source]¶
class Pandemic.X86.X86.SegReg(value, adjust_value=False)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Register

Class representing segment registers.

class Pandemic.X86.X86.X86DecodedInstruction(ea, instr, length, flow=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for packaging the results of instruction decoding. In particular, the Instruction class does not indicate the address of an instruction, nor its length, nor which addresses to which the instruction may transfer control.

Variables:
  • ea (integer) – the instruction’s address
  • instr (Instruction) – the instruction itself
  • length (integer) – the length of the instruction
  • flow (FlowType) – the instruction’s successor addresses
CreateFlow()[source]¶

Inspect the instruction and its length, and determine which type of control flow it exhibits (passes control to the next instruction, returns, conditional jump, etc). For a complete listing of flow types, see the ASMFlow module.

class Pandemic.X86.X86.XMMReg(value, adjust_value=False)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86Internal.Register

Class representing XMM registers.

Pandemic.X86.X86ByteStream module¶

Byte stream interface. To support any form of input, derive a class from StreamObj and override GetByteInternal().

class Pandemic.X86.X86ByteStream.StreamObj(bytes)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for acquiring bytes from a source.

Byte()[source]¶

Check to ensure that we have not consumed more than 16 bytes (for that would signal an illegal instruction). If not, invoke GetByteInternal() and return the result.

Return type:8-bit integer
Raises:InvalidInstruction if more than 16 bytes have been consumed since the last call to SetPos().
Dword()[source]¶

Consume a dword from the stream and return it.

Return type:32-bit integer
Raises:InvalidInstruction if more than 16 bytes have been consumed since the last call to SetPos().
GetByteInternal()[source]¶

Consume a byte from the stream and return it. This function shall be the only one needed to override in derived classes, when changing the source from which a byte is consumed.

Return type:8-bit integer
Init()[source]¶

Initializes position variables.

Pos()[source]¶

Return the current position of the stream.

Return type:integer
SetPos(ea)[source]¶

Set the current position of the stream to ea.

Parameters:ea (integer) –
Word()[source]¶

Consume a word from the stream and return it.

Return type:16-bit integer
Raises:InvalidInstruction if more than 16 bytes have been consumed since the last call to SetPos().

Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM module¶

Classes for representing ModRM16 and ModRM32 memory expressions. Also contains functionality to decode a ModRM expression, given a stream of bytes (as in X86ByteStream.StreamObj), and to produce an encoded ModRM expression given the constituent parts of a memory expression.

class Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.ModRM16(mod=None, ggg=None, rm=None, disp=None, dispsize=0)[source]¶

Bases: object

Describes a ModRM/16 object.

Decode(stream)[source]¶

Pull the fields of the ModR/M-16 apart, and consume a displacement if specified. Set the internal state of the object accordingly. This is the “preliminary” decoding phase, after which the stream object is no longer necessary. To actually obtain the parts of the memory expression specified by the ModRM, call Interpret().

Parameters:stream (X86ByteStream) – byte stream from which to consume bytes
Raises:InvalidInstruction if stream consumed 16 or more bytes
Disp¶

The ModRM memory expression’s displacement, an integer.

DispSize¶

The ModRM memory expression’s displacement size in bytes (0, 1, or 2 for ModRM16; 0, 1, or 4 for ModRM32).

Encode()[source]¶

Concatenate the fields MOD, GGG, and RM together to form the ModRM-16 byte. If a displacement is present, turn it into a list of little-endian bytes.

Return type:integer list
EncodeAdditional(b)[source]¶

Encode something between the ModRM and displacement. Not used in the ModRM16 class, but overridden in the ModRM32 class.

Parameters:b (integer list) – ModRM byte as a list
Return type:integer list
EncodeFromParts(BaseReg, IndexReg, Disp)[source]¶

Given base and index registers, and an integer displacement, set the internal state to the corresponding integer values. We must interpret the arguments and determine which special cases apply, if any.

Parameters:
  • BaseReg (R16Elt) – base register (or None)
  • IndexReg (R16Elt) – index register (or None)
  • Disp (integer) – displacement (may be 0 or None)
Raises:

Exception – if BaseReg and IndexReg are an illegal register pair
GGG¶

The ModRM’s middle 3 bits.

Interpret()[source]¶

For a ModRM16 object whose MOD field is not 3 (i.e., the ModRM16 object specifies a memory location and not a register), examine the fields of the object and return a 4-tuple describing the 16-bit memory expression.

Return type:(R16Elt, R16Elt, integer, integer)
Returns:A 4-tuple containing a base register, index register, integer displacement, and displacement size in bytes. The register components may be None; the displacement may be 0 or None.
Raises:assertion failure if MOD is 3.
MOD¶

The ModRM’s top 2 bits.

RM¶

The ModRM’s low 3 bits.

init(mask, mod=None, ggg=None, rm=None, disp=None, dispsize=0)[source]¶
class Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.ModRM32(mod=None, ggg=None, rm=None, sf=None, idx=None, base=None, disp=None, dispsize=0)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.ModRM16

Decode(stream)[source]¶

Pull the fields of the ModR/M-32 apart, and consume a displacement if specified. Set the internal state of the object accordingly. This is the “preliminary” decoding phase, after which the stream object is no longer necessary. To actually obtain the parts of the memory expression specified by the ModRM, call Interpret().

Parameters:stream (X86ByteStream) – byte stream from which to consume bytes
Raises:InvalidInstruction if stream consumed 16 or more bytes
EncodeAdditional(b)[source]¶

If a SIBBase SIB was required, append its encoding to the parameter b. Otherwise, return b as-is.

Parameters:b (integer list) – ModRM byte as a list
Return type:integer list
EncodeFromParts(BaseReg, IndexReg, ScaleFac, Disp)[source]¶

Given base and index registers, a scale factor, and an integer displacement, set the internal state to the corresponding integer values. We must interpret the arguments and determine which special cases apply, if any.

Parameters:
  • BaseReg (R32Elt) – base register (or None)
  • IndexReg (R32Elt) – index register (or None)
  • ScaleFac (integer) – scale factor (0-3)
  • Disp (integer) – displacement (may be 0 or None)
Interpret()[source]¶

For a ModRM32 object whose MOD field is not 3 (i.e., the ModRM32 object specifies a memory location and not a register), examine the fields of the object and return a 5-tuple describing the 32-bit memory expression.

Return type:(R32Elt, R32Elt,integer,integer,integer)
Returns:A 5-tuple containing a base register, index register, scale factor, integer displacement, and displacement size in bytes. The register components may be None; the displacement may be None.
Raises:assertion failure if MOD is 3.
SIB¶

An optional Scale-Index-Byte (SIB) SIBBase object.

class Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.SIBBase(ss_=None, idx_=None, base_=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class is only meaningful for 32-bit memory expressions encoded via ModRM, and only if a SIB (Scale-Index-Base) byte is required.

BASE¶

The middle three bits of a SIB are the base register.

Encode()[source]¶

Concatenate the fields SCALE, INDEX, and BASE together to form the ModRM-16 byte. If a displacement is present, turn it into a list of little-endian bytes.

Return type:integer list
INDEX¶

The middle three bits of a SIB are the index register.

SCALE¶

The top two bits of a SIB are the scale factor. * 0: 1 * 1: 2 * 2: 4 * 3: 8

init(ss=None, idx=None, base=None, disp=None)[source]¶
Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.little_endian_bytes(imm, n)[source]¶

Return a list of n 8-bit integers from the bytes of imm

Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.modrm_16 = [(Bx, Si), (Bx, Di), (Bp, Si), (Bp, Di), (Si, None), (Di, None), (Bp, None), (Bx, None)]¶

The register values specified by the RM field of a ModRM16 object.

Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.sign_extend_8_16(b8)[source]¶

Sign-extend an 8-bit integer to a 16-bit one.

Pandemic.X86.X86ModRM.sign_extend_8_32(b8)[source]¶

Sign-extend an 8-bit integer to a 32-bit one.

Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperand module¶

This file contains an enumeration (in the style of Enumerate) for abstract operand types in X86.

Bases: Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.EnumElt

Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions module¶

This module defines the classes for the Abstract Operand Type Description Language, all of which derive from X86AOTDL. Additionally, the list AOTtoAOTDL contains one X86AOTDL object for each AOTElt abstract operand type.

class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.AddrPrefix(yes, no)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that differs depending upon the address size prefix.

Variables:
  • yes (X86AOTDL) – if the prefix is present
  • no (X86AOTDL) – if the prefix is absent
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.Exact(v)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies an Operand exactly.

Variables:value (Operand) – the precise operand specified
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.ExactSeg(v)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies a Mem16 or Mem32 exactly, where the segment is allowed to differ.

Variables:value (MemExpr) – the precise operand specified
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.GPart(a)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies any Register within some family (i.e., some class derived from Register).

Variables:archetype (Register) – the register family specified
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.ImmEnc(a)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies an operand that is encoded as an immediate. Its archetype field may specify:

  • An Immediate operand
  • A MemExpr, which is not permitted to use base or index registers
  • A JccTarget
  • A FarTarget
Variables:archetype (Operand) – the type of operand described by this AOTDL
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.RegOrMem(reg, mem)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies either any Register from some family, or a memory expression specified by access size. Either component may be illegal; in which case, the corresponding member is None.

Variables:
  • reg (Register) – the register family specified, or None
  • mem (MSElt) – the memory access size, or None
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.SignedImm(a)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that specifies an operand that is encoded as an 8-bit immediate, which is interpreted as a larger value. Its archetype field may specify:

  • An Immediate operand
  • A JccTarget
Variables:archetype (Operand) – the type of operand described by this AOTDL
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.SizePrefix(yes, no)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL

AOTDL element that differs depending upon the operand size prefix.

Variables:
  • yes (X86AOTDL) – if the prefix is present
  • no (X86AOTDL) – if the prefix is absent
class Pandemic.X86.X86InternalOperandDescriptions.X86AOTDL[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for all AOTDL elements.

A list mapping AOTElt members to X86AOTDL objects.

Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable module¶

X86 instructions have “encodings” associated with them. Encodings are represented as classes that derive from X86Enc. Encodings describe the types of the operands, as well as whether they require any special treatment while converting the instructions into bytes:

  • Ordinary requires no special treatment.
  • Native16 encodings require size prefixes.
  • ModRMGroup encodings set the Ordinary’s GGG member.
class Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.ModRMGroup(ggg, bytes, ops)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.X86Enc

The encoding method class for X86 instructions that are part of a ModRM group, and thus require that the encoder’s ModRM member GGG be set to a specific value.

Variables:ggg (integer) – The group entry number (GGG value).
Encode(encoder)[source]¶

Native16 instruction encodings must set the GGG member of encoder.

Parameters:encoder (X86Encoder.X86Encoder) – Encoder object
class Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.Native16(bytes, ops)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.X86Enc

The encoding method class for X86 instructions that require an opsize prefix in order to be encoded.

Encode(encoder)[source]¶

Native16 instruction encodings must set the sizepfx member of encoder.

Parameters:encoder (X86Encoder.X86Encoder) – Encoder object
class Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.Ordinary(bytes, ops)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.X86Enc

The encoding method class for most X86 instruction encodings.

Encode(encoder)[source]¶

Ordinary instruction encodings don’t modify encoder.

Parameters:encoder (X86Encoder.X86Encoder) – Encoder object
class Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.X86Enc(bytes, ops)[source]¶

Bases: object

The base class for all X86 instruction encodings.

Variables:
  • bytes – instruction stem bytes
  • ops – list of abstract operand types
Encode(encoder)[source]¶

This method is responsible for modifying the encoder object if the encoding method requires that.

Parameters:encoder (X86Encoder.X86Encoder) – Encoder object
Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.v(m)[source]¶
Pandemic.X86.X86EncodeTable.mnem_to_encodings¶

This list maps an X86 mnemonic to its list of encodings, i.e., a list of X86Enc.

Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker module¶

The type-checker for Operand and Instruction objects. It is important for its own sake (to ensure that user-created Instruction objects are valid within the X86 instruction set), as well as during encoding (to determine how the instruction should be encoded). It supports three interfaces:

  • check(), to check a single Operand against a single AOTElt;
  • TypeCheckInstruction_exn(), to check an instruction against a list of AOTElt types and raise a X86TypeCheckError on failure;
  • TypeCheckInstruction_opt(), to check an instruction against a list of AOTElt types and return None on failure.
Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.AddrPFX(b, t=None)[source]¶

Either return a new TypeCheckInfo object with the addro field set to b if t is None, or update t with that information.

Variables:
  • b (bool) – address size prefix required
  • t (TypeCheckInfo) – existing TypeCheckInfo object or None
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.MATCHES()[source]¶

Return an empty TypeCheckInfo object.

Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.SegPFX(s, t=None)[source]¶

Either return a new TypeCheckInfo object with the sego field set to s if t is None, or update t with that information.

Variables:
  • s (SegElt) – segment prefix required
  • t (TypeCheckInfo) – existing TypeCheckInfo object or None
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.SizePFX(b, t=None)[source]¶

Either return a new TypeCheckInfo object with the sizeo field set to b if t is None, or update t with that information.

Variables:
  • b (bool) – operand size prefix required
  • t (TypeCheckInfo) – existing TypeCheckInfo object or None
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
class Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.TypeCheckInfo(sizeo=None, addro=None, sego=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class holds information about the overrides required by an operand. Any member may be None, in which case that particular override is not meaningful for the operand.

Variables:
  • sizeo (bool) – operand size OPSIZE prefix required or not
  • addro (bool) – address size ADDRSIZE prefix required or not
  • sego (SegElt) – a segment, if such a prefix is required
exception Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.X86TypeCheckError(str)[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

This exception may be thrown during type-checking. One interface method allows exceptions to pass through; another catches them and returns None.

class Pandemic.X86.X86TypeChecker.X86TypeChecker[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.Util.Visitor.Visitor2

This Visitor2 class implements type-checking for X86 instructions.

Default(op1, enc)[source]¶

This method is invoked when the operand op1 and AOTDL enc were incompatible, the default case for a Visitor object.

Parameters:
  • op1 (Operand) – X86 operand which failed type-checking
  • enc (X86AOTDL) – AOTDL which failed type-checking
Return type:

None
MakeMethodName(op1, enc)[source]¶

We override this method from the Visitor class to simplify the design. In particular, we separate the types that may be held by ImmEnc and SignedImm operand descriptions.

Parameters:
  • op1 (Operand) – X86 operand to check
  • enc (X86AOTDL) – AOTDL for which to choose a visit_() method.
Return type:

string
Returns:

a string naming one of the visit_ methods.
TypeCheckInstruction_exn(instr, aops)[source]¶

Checks the instruction’s operands against a list of abstract operand types. This particular variant of the function will throw an exception with information as to why the instruction was not accepted. Another method, TypeCheckInstruction_opt(), catches exceptions and returns None if one was raised.

Parameters:
  • instr (X86.Instruction) – instruction to type-check
  • aops (AOTElt list) – list of abstract operand types to check against
Return type:

( bool , bool, .SegElt ) tuple
Raises:

X86TypeCheckError – if the instruction or one of its operands did not match.
TypeCheckInstruction_opt(instr, aops)[source]¶

Calls TypeCheckInstruction_exn(). If it throws an exception, return None.

Parameters:
  • instr (X86.Instruction) – instruction to type-check
  • aops (AOTElt list) – list of abstract operand types to check against
Return type:

( bool , bool, .SegElt ) tuple
check(aop, opnd)[source]¶

The main interface method that clients should call when type-checking a single abstract operand / x86 operand pair. Look up the X86AOTDL for aop, and check its compatibility with opnd.

Parameters:
  • aop (AOTElt) –
  • opnd (X86Internal.Operand) –
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
Returns:

Information about required prefix overrides, or None if opnd was incompatible with aop.
lenient_sizes = set([OFPEnv, OFPEnvLow, OSimdState])¶

For these abstract operand types, don’t check the sizes.

For Exact AOTDL elements, op must match a’s value member exactly.

Parameters:

  • a (Exact) –

TypeCheckInfo
visit_ExactSeg(op, a)[source]¶

For ExactSeg AOTDL elements, op must match a’s value member exactly, or it must match value when value’s Seg attribute is changed to that of op. In the latter case, the return value must indicate that a segment override prefix is required.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (ExactSeg) –
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo

For GPart AOTDL elements, ensure that the operand type specified in a’s archetype member has the same type as the operand op.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (GPart) –
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_Immediate_FarTarget(op, a)[source]¶

For ImmEnc AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type FarTarget, ensure that the operand op has the same type as archetype.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (ImmEnc) – ImmEnc with AP16 or AP32 archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_Immediate_Immediate(op, a)[source]¶

For ImmEnc AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type ImmEnc, ensure that the operand op has the same type as archetype.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (ImmEnc) – ImmEnc with Immediate archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_Immediate_JccTarget(op, a)[source]¶

For ImmEnc AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type JccTarget, ensure that the operand op also has type JccTarget.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (ImmEnc) – ImmEnc with JccTarget archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_Immediate_MemExpr(op, a)[source]¶

For ImmEnc AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type MemExpr, ensure that the operand op is indeed a MemExpr object that consists solely of a displacement (Disp member) – in particular, that BaseReg and IndexReg are None. As for all MemExpr operands, check for address-size and segment-override prefixes.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (ImmEnc) – ImmEnc with MemExpr archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_RegOrMem(op, m)[source]¶

For RegOrMem AOTDL elements, check both possibilities: that op may match m’s reg component, or that it may match the mem component (specified by a MSElt enumeration element). When comparing memories, issue any necessary address and/or segment override prefixes. The size of the memory is part of the comparison, unless the abstract operand type is one of those for which size comparisons should not occur (see lenient_sizes).

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • m (RegOrMem) –
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_SignExtImm_Id(op, a)[source]¶

For SignedImm AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type Id, ensure that the operand op is an Immediate with a value that fits into 8-bits and can be sign-extended to the same 32-bit constant.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (SignedImm) – SignedImm with Id archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_SignExtImm_Iw(op, a)[source]¶

For SignedImm AOTDL elements whose archetype members are of type Iw, ensure that the operand op is an Immediate with a value that fits into 8-bits and can be sign-extended to the same 16-bit constant.

Parameters:
  • op (Operand) – X86 operand
  • a (SignedImm) – SignedImm with Iw archetype
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo
visit_SizePrefix(op, z)[source]¶

Used when visiting prefixed operand types. First, try to visit the member where a prefix is required (i.e., z’s yes member). If it matches, update the information returned to indicate that the prefix was required. Otherwise, visit the member where no prefix is required (i.e., z’s no member), and if that matches, return the flags from the match plus a flag indicating that an override is possible (but not required). Otherwise, no match, i.e. return None.

Parameters:
  • op1 (Operand) – X86 operand
  • z (SizePrefix) –
Return type:

TypeCheckInfo

Pandemic.X86.X86Encoder module¶

This module implements the encoder for X86 instructions, in the X86Encoder class.

Pandemic.X86.X86Encoder.PrefixOfSeg = {ES: 38, CS: 46, SS: 54, DS: 62, FS: 100, GS: 101}¶

Mapping from segments to their appropriate prefix bytes.

class Pandemic.X86.X86Encoder.X86Encoder[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.Util.Visitor.Visitor2

This Visitor2 class is responsible for turning X86 Instruction objects into their encoded binary representation, i.e., lists of bytes. All of its variables are internal; users of this class should only interact with it through the EncodeInstruction() and EncodeInstructions() methods.

Variables:
  • tc (X86TypeChecker.X86TypeChecker) – A type-checker object
  • group1pfx (PF1Elt) – A group #1 prefix or None
  • stem – Instruction stem
  • segpfx (SegElt) – A segment prefix or None
  • sizepfx (bool) – Whether an OPSIZE operand size prefix is required
  • addrpfx (bool) – Whether an ADDRSIZE address size prefix is required
  • immediates – Any operands that are encoded as bytes after the prefixes, stem, and optional ModRM
AppendImmediate(imm, n)[source]¶

Append an n-byte immediate imm to the immediates class member, as a little-endian list of bytes.

Parameters:
  • imm (integer) –
  • n (integer) –
EncodeInstruction(instr, addr=0)[source]¶

Given an instruction, look up its mnemonic in mnem_to_encodings. Using the type-checker member tc, try to find a suitable encoding. Encode the instruction with that encoding, and return the byte list.

Parameters:
  • instr (Instruction) – The x86 instruction to encode
  • addr (integer) – The address at which to encode
Return type:

integer list
EncodeInstructions(instrs, addr=0)[source]¶

Encode one or more instruction using the EncodeInstruction() method. Call it in a loop, updating the address after each instruction is encoded.

Parameters:
  • instr (Instruction list) – The list of x86 instructions to encode
  • addr (integer) – The address at which to encode
Return type:

integer list
Returns:

The bytes of all instructions in a single list.
MakeMethodName(op1, enc)[source]¶

We override this method from the Visitor class to simplify the design. Since the ImmEnc can hold different types of operands in its archetype field, we separate them out into one method per type. SignedImm is similar. For RegOrMem, we have different methods depending upon whether op1 is a Register object or a MemExpr.

Parameters:
  • op1 (Operand) –
  • enc (X86AOTDL) –
ModRM¶

A ModR/M object. Using a property makes this very slick: we initialize the object to None, where a ModRM16 or ModRM32 object is created on-the-fly the first time this member is accessed.

Reset()[source]¶

Clear all held state within the encoder object.

  • a (AddrPrefix) –

Parameters:

  • i (Exact) –

Parameters:

  • i (ImmEnc) –
visit_Immediate_JccTarget(op, i)[source]¶

For JccTargets, we treat them all as long jumps. These are “relatively- addressed”, meaning dependent upon the location at which it is encoded. The beginning of this instruction is held in the addr member. We add up the size of the prefixes and stem so far to decide where the instruction ends, then subtract that from the destination address. We use full-sized displacements to avoid some headaches.

Parameters:
  • op (JccTarget) –
  • i (ImmEnc) –
visit_Immediate_MemExpr(op, i)[source]¶

For ImmEnc where the op is a MemExpr, write its Disp member as an immediate (2 bytes for Mem16, 4 bytes for Mem32.

Parameters:
  • op (MemExpr) –
  • i (ImmEnc) –
visit_RegOrMem_Mem16(mem, m)[source]¶

For RegOrMem where the op a Mem16, invoke the EncodeFromParts() method using the parts of the memory expression mem.

Parameters:
  • mem (Mem16) –
  • m (RegOrMem) –
visit_RegOrMem_Mem32(mem, m)[source]¶

For RegOrMem where the op a Mem32, invoke the EncodeFromParts() method using the parts of the memory expression mem.

Parameters:
  • mem (Mem32) –
  • m (RegOrMem) –
visit_RegOrMem_Register(op, m)[source]¶

For RegOrMem where the op a Register, set the ModRM field MOD to 3, and field RM to the Register object op’s IntValue().

Parameters:
  • op (Register) –
  • m (RegOrMem) –

Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable module¶

This module defines the classes for the Decoder Description Language, all of which derive from X86DECDL. The actual decoding table for X86 instructions is exported in the variable decoding_table.

class Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.Predicated(orr, reg)[source]¶

This class of decoder entries selects between two different possibilities, depending upon the cond() method. I.e., cond() is responsible for checking the state of the decoder to determine which entry – either overridden or regular – should be invoked.

Variables:
  • overridden (X86DECDL) – Entry to use when cond() returns True
  • regular (X86DECDL) – Entry to use when cond() returns False
cond(decoder)[source]¶

This method is overridden in derived classes to customize which decoder entry is selected.

Parameters:decoder (X86Decoder.X86Decoder) –
Return type:bool
Returns:A bool dictating which X86DECDL entry to use.
decode(decoder)[source]¶

Calls the decode() method of either overridden or regular, depending upon the return value of cond().

Parameters:decoder (X86Decoder.X86Decoder) –
Return type:(MnemElt, AOTElt list)

class Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.SSE(no, rep, size, repne)[source]¶

Decoder entry for SSE instructions. It selects one of four decoder entries depending upon the REP, REPNZ, and OPSIZE prefixes.

Variables:
  • no (X86DECDL) – Entry to use with no prefixes
  • rep (X86DECDL) – Entry to use with the REP prefix
  • size (X86DECDL) – Entry to use with the OPSIZE prefix
  • repne (X86DECDL) – Entry to use with the REPNE prefix
repne = None¶

Select one of the entries based upon complex decoding logic, and call its decode() method.

Parameters:decoder (X86Decoder.X86Decoder) –
Return type:(MnemElt, AOTElt list)
Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.SSE66(se)[source]¶

Shortcut to use for SSE when only the OPSIZE prefix entry is valid.

Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.SSENo(no)[source]¶

Shortcut to use for SSE when only the non-prefixed entry is valid.

Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.SSENo66(no, se)[source]¶

Shortcut to use for SSE when only the OPSIZE prefix and non-prefixed entries are valid.

class Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.X86DECDL[source]¶

X86 Decoder Description Language (X86DECDL) base class.

Pandemic.X86.X86DecodeTable.decoding_table¶

This array replicates the Intel Manuals’ Opcode Maps, in terms of the X86DECDL classes defined in this module.

Pandemic.X86.X86Decoder module¶

This module provides the class X86Decoder to decode X86 machine code. For flexibility, this class consumes bytes from an X86ByteStream.StreamObj. Owing to this design decision, we can obtain the bytes from any source, as long as we can implement the StreamObj interface around that byte source. For example, we could use IDA’s get_byte(), map a PE file into a flat memory view and index into that, use a debugger’s capabilities to read from memory, etc.

class Pandemic.X86.X86Decoder.X86Decoder(stream)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.Util.Visitor.Visitor

Decode(ea)[source]¶

The main interface to the decoder functionality.

Parameters:ea (integer) – The address from which to decode
Return type:X86DecodedInstruction
DecodePrefixes()[source]¶

Consume all of the prefixes before the instruction stem, and update the class variables accordingly. When we consume a non-prefix byte, we stop and return it.

Return type:integer
DecodeStem(first_byte)[source]¶

Given the first byte of the stem (as read by DecodePrefixes above), examine it and any subsequent escape bytes to determine the stem.

Parameters:first_byte (integer) –
Return type:integer
Returns:A stem number from 0x000-0x3FF.
GetSegment()[source]¶

Get the segment to use for a memory expression. If there is a segment prefix, use that. If there is no ModRM, use DS. If there is a ModRM, inspect the base register and use either DS or SS accordingly.

Return type:SegElt
MakeMethodName(enc)[source]¶

We override this method from the Visitor class to simplify the design. We segregate the ImmEnc, RegOrMem, and SignedImm encodings by their type so as to choose a specialized visit_() method.

Parameters:enc (X86AOTDL) –
Return type:string
ModRM¶

As in X86Encoder, the use of class properties makes ModRM accesses very slick. We don’t have to explicitly store a table describing which stems need a ModRM, like most other disassemblers. Instead, we simply wait until some part of the code touches the ModRM property for the first time. At that point, we parse the ModRM (depending upon the address-size prefix) and store it within the object.

Reset()[source]¶

Reset the variables held in the decoder.

oJCommon(x)[source]¶

Common method for decoding jumps. Calculate the target of the jump, and then truncate to 16-bits if there was an address size prefix.

Parameters:x (integer) – displacement from the end of the current instruction
Return type:JccTarget

visit_ExactSeg(i)[source]¶

visit_GPart_SegReg(g)[source]¶

For GPart operand types describing segment registers, check to see that the register number is in bound (0-5). If not, raise an InvalidInstruction exception. Otherwise, return the segment register numbered by ModRM GGG field.

For RegOrMem when memory is specified, create a Mem16 or Mem32 object depending upon address size, using the information from X86Decoder.ModRM.
